III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4109
Section Program statement
Description (1) An institution shall have and follow a current written program
statement which specifically addresses all of the following:
1

(c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission, care,
safety, and supervision, methods for addressing residents' needs,
implementation of treatment plans, and discharge of residents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation There are concerns with the facility's use of blanket pause
restrictions that prevent youth from engaging in supportive,
therapeutic activities in response to youth trauma behaviors.
Investigation Interviews:
Complainant was interviewed via telephone on August 11,
2025, and reported the facility has blanket consequences for
youth and their behaviors when each youth has their own
unique trauma and triggers. Complainant stated Youth A’s
bedroom was cleared of items and Youth A was not allowed to go
off site after going AWOL due to the facility’s blanket pause
restriction. Complainant reported having one on one time, away
from the facility with Youth A would have helped Youth A process
what occurred and been a supportive therapeutic outing.
Complainant reported clearing Youth A’s room of Youth A’s
belongings is a trigger and reminder of all the other times Youth A
has had to pack and move. Complainant stated that Youth A
reported to her staff told Youth A she was bad; telling Youth A if
you did what you were supposed to do then you could go off
campus.
Facility Administrator (FA) was interviewed face to face at the
facility on August 18, 2025. FA reported the purpose of pause
time is for a youth to take a break, reflect on their behavior, and
talk with staff with the intent to be helpful not hurtful. FA stated
during this time the youth and staff discuss the situation, what
could have been different and identify other coping techniques
that could have been used. FA described when a youth is on
pause, the youth does not earn the added incentives of going on
outings; the additional activities are what are paused. FA stated
the youth are held accountable and taught socially acceptable
behaviors in a trauma informed approach. FA reported that when
youth arrive at the facility an individualized trauma-informed safety
plan is created with the youth. FA described the youth, along with
the therapist, identify triggers and situations that can make the
youth uncomfortable and outline what is helpful to the youth to
gain control and feel safe and write it in the safety plan. FA stated
the plan is reviewed by every staff member. FA reported the
facility has programming with restrictions and consequences for
every youth. FA stated the consequences for behaviors are the
2

same across the board, so youth understand the expectations and
do not feel staff are showing favoritism to any one youth.
Assistant Facility Administrator (AFA) was interviewed face
to face at the facility on August 18, 2025. AFA described the
first time Youth A went AWOL AFA had a conversation reminding
Youth A of the expectations and protocol of the facility when a
youth goes AWOL. AFA stated the second time Youth A went
AWOL, Youth A was placed on pause and given the option to
clear her room, have staff help her clear her room or staff would
clear the room for Youth A. AFA reported Youth A was given the
day to decide how she would like to move forward and time to
process the consequence. AFA stated this is the same
consequence for every youth at the facility who goes AWOL. AFA
reported Youth A shared she feels safest at night, roaming the
streets by herself. AFA stated staff are working with Youth A to
help her understand how unsafe that can be and develop other
options to help her feel safe and identify what is making her feel
unsafe.
AFA described Youth A as a pacer and it has been approved and
developed in Youth A’s trauma informed plan for Youth A to be
allowed to walk to help her calm down. AFA reported Youth A
stated she does not like bugs, so she does not like to walk/pace in
the backyard, which is identified as the place for youth to walk to
help calm themselves. AFA stated Youth A’s individual trauma
plan allows Youth A to pace in front of the facility in a certain area
so staff can maintain eyesight. AFA reported the trauma plans are
individual to the youth and help the youth and staff identify how
best to work with the youth based on the youth’s trauma. AFA
stated programing and consequences are the same for all the
youth at the facility, so all youth know the expectations with
consistency and structure being provided.
Youth A was interviewed face to face at the facility on August
18, 2025. Youth A reported she likes it at the facility and
understands the rules, programming and expectations. Youth A
stated there are staff at the facility she likes and can talk with
when she is feeling upset. Youth A described having therapy
regularly in the one month she has been at the facility.
Youth A described going AWOL recently, having items removed
from her room and not being able to leave the facility. Youth A
stated, “this is how it goes down for everyone.” Youth A reported
AFA talked with her about not being able to leave the facility and
items having to be removed from Youth A’s room. Youth A denied
3

any staff ever telling her she was bad. Youth A reported that any
youth who goes AWOL is placed on pause and has items taken
from their bedroom. Youth A stated one youth (could not recall
the youth’s name) who went AWOL was able to leave the facility
while on pause. Youth A described the youth being able to go to
the cemetery. Youth A reported this was the only time she could
recall youth being treated differently by staff.
Youth A denied any staff talking with her about things that make
her mad, upset or feel unsafe. Youth A stated when she is upset
the staff offer for her to sit outside, go for a walk, or draw. Youth A
reported staff offer these options when she is getting upset.
Youth B was interviewed face to face at the facility on August
18, 2025. Youth B reported it “was cool here” at the facility.
Youth B stated when she first arrived at the facility a safety plan
was completed with Therapist. Youth B described telling
Therapist what calming techniques worked best for her and it
being individualized. Youth B reported all the staff know the
youths’ safety plans and how best to work with each one of them.
Youth B stated when she first arrived staff went over programing,
expectations and consequences. Youth B reported in the first few
days if youth do not follow programing staff will remind the youth if
you do that again this is what will happen. Youth B stated, “it’s
like staff giving you a pass but it does not last long.” Youth B
reported everyone [youth] should be treated the same, but they
are not. Youth B stated one time a youth who was on pause was
able to leave the facility and go to the cemetery to see her
grandmother’s grave. Youth B reported she did not feel it was fair
but “kind of understood because it was the youth’s grandmother.”
Youth B denied having any concerns with staff. Youth B stated
she has not heard any youth be called bad. Youth B reported in
group negative or bad behavior are talked about with different
ways to express that behavior.
Youth C was interviewed face to face at the facility on August
18, 2025. Youth C described the facility as being “okay.” Youth C
stated she feels safe and has staff to talk with when she is upset.
Youth C reported when she first arrived at the facility Therapist
and Case Manager went over the handbook, program, rules and
expectations. Youth C described some things as being unfair at
the facility where youth are not always treated the same. Youth C
stated one day Youth D was “cussing” out staff and the next day
was still allowed to go to the cemetery. Youth C reported she did
4

not think it was fair for Youth D to be rewarded for her behavior.
Youth C stated staff do not treat all the youth the same when they
[youth] are upset. Youth C reported that each youth has different
things that help calm them so that is what staff offer or try to do to
help the youth calm down. Youth D denied having any concerns
with staff or the facility. Youth D reported she has not heard any
staff tell a youth they are bad. Youth D stated she has heard staff
tell youth they are making a bad choice.
Case Manager was interviewed face to face at the facility on
August 18, 2025. Case Manager reported that when youth come
to the facility they are given the program policy to review. Case
Manager stated she goes over the program, levels, rules and
consequences with the youth. Case Manager described Therapist
as being the one who develops the safety plan with the youth.
Case Manager reported that the rules and consequences are the
same for all the youth, but staff utilize individual safety plans and
interventions to help each youth through their trauma.
Therapist was interviewed via telephone on August 18, 2025.
Therapist reported that an individualized safety plan is created for
every youth entering the facility. Therapist described the plan
being developed by the youth and herself and both sign the plan.
Therapist stated Youth A identified wanting to work on anger
management, identified triggers and provided interventions staff
could do to help her with managing her anger. Therapist
described Youth A as having good insight and actively participated
in the plan.
Therapist reported it is important for all the youth at the facility to
see staff as being consistent with the rules, expectations and
consequences. Therapist stated staff need to understand each
youth’s triggers and the coping skills each youth has identified to
help the youth use appropriate skills when escalated. Therapist
reported all staff are made aware of each youth’s individualized
trauma informed safety plan and are involved in regular staff
meetings to discuss the individual needs of each youth.
Documents Reviewed:
• Youth A’s Trauma-Informed Individualized Safety Plan,
signed by Youth A and Therapist. Triggers, warning signs
of Youth A getting upset and what staff can do/say to help
Youth A feel safe were identified in the plan.
• New Hope Restrictions, Behaviors, Consequences Policy.
Policy states, “The Assistant Facility Administrator will
conduct a thorough review monthly to ensure fidelity to the
5

system and to ensure Phase Pause Statuses are
administered appropriate, consistently, and fairly for all,
given the totality of circumstances.”
Analysis The facility is found in compliance as per staff and youth
interviews, policy is being followed by staff to be consistent in
programing, expectations and consequences with youth. Staff
and youth interviews describe each youth having a trauma-
informed individualized safety plan utilized by staff to engage in
supportive therapeutic responses to each individual youth and
their behavior.
Consultation:
Consultation was offered to the facility to continue to examine why
youth are displaying certain behaviors and update the trauma-
informed individualized safety plan more frequently as the facility
gains better insight of the youth, the triggers and supports staff
can utilize.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
